diagnosis.score_summary: Aquaphor demonstrates exceptional strategic discipline, maintaining 'Medical Authority' across 15 of 17 markers. The minor deviations in USP and Values represent a pragmatic adaptation to the Amazon platform rather than strategic drift, though the brand must be careful not to trade its human authority for pure chemistry.

truth_1.headline: Format Over Fame
truth_1.gap_description: Your Strategy claims ownership of 'The Hero' (the legendary Aquaphor brand equity), but the PDP pivots to own 'The Tech' (the Stick format). You are commoditizing yourself. Instead of selling the 'Magic of Aquaphor in a stick,' you are selling 'A Stick that happens to be Aquaphor.'
truth_1.why_matters: When you shift ownership from Brand Equity to Format Convenience, you lower the barrier to entry for competitors. Any private label can make a stick. Only you can make Aquaphor. You are trading long-term moat for short-term conversion.
truth_1.do_this_now: Revise the Product Title and Hero Bullets to lead with 'The Original Healing Ointment' phrasing before mentioning the 'Mess-Free Stick.' Re-anchor the value in the formula, not the plastic.

truth_2.headline: Data Over Dialogue
truth_2.gap_description: Your Strategy aims for 'Explained' transparency (3/5)—simplifying science for the user. The PDP drops to 'The Spec Sheet' (1/5), listing percentages and chemical names without translation. You have replaced the helpful pharmacist with a cold ingredient label.
truth_2.why_matters: The Amazon shopper is in 'Panic Mode' (Marker 15). They don't want to know the percentage of Petrolatum; they want to know *why it's safe*. High-density technical data creates friction for the layperson, potentially losing the 'Safety First' parent who feels overwhelmed by the chemistry.
truth_2.do_this_now: In the A+ Content 'Ingredients' module, add a 'What It Does' line under 'Petrolatum 30%'. Translate the spec sheet back into human benefit: 'Petrolatum 30% (Creates a protective barrier to lock in moisture).'

truth_3.headline: Molecules Over Medicine
truth_3.gap_description: Strategically, your authority comes from 'Derm-Validation' (2/5)—a human endorsement. On the PDP, the primary authority signal shifts to 'Pure Clinical' (1/5)—focusing on the molecular reality of Petrolatum. You are drifting from 'Doctor Recommended' to 'Lab Created.'
truth_3.why_matters: Human authority triggers trust; chemical authority triggers scrutiny. By leading so heavily with the chemical composition on the PDP, you risk looking synthetic rather than therapeutic. You lose the warmth of the 'Caregiver' archetype.
truth_3.do_this_now: Bring the 'Dermatologist Recommended' badge up to the second image in the carousel. Ensure the human element (the doctor's choice) visually outweighs the chemical element (the ingredient list).

truth_4.headline: The God Complex
truth_4.gap_description: Your Personality is healthy (90%), but the Power Dynamic has drifted from 'Specialist' (4/5) to 'Deity' (5/5). Phrases like 'Will this product damage my skin? No.' are borderline arrogant. You are one step away from being perceived as cold and dismissive rather than authoritative.
truth_4.evidence: [PERSONALITY] Alignment: 90% | Risk: Power Dynamic slider at max (Strategy 4/5 vs. Reality 5/5)
truth_4.why_matters: A brand that positions itself as a 'Deity' creates distance. If a customer has a bad experience, they don't complain; they revolt. Maintaining a tone of 'Specialist' (4/5) keeps the brand accessible. 'Deity' (5/5) makes it untouchable and unlovable.
truth_4.do_this_now: Soften the Q&A section in the A+ Content. Change 'Will this product damage my skin? No.' to 'Designed for safety: Our formula is clinically tested to be gentle on sensitive skin.' Return to the posture of a helper, not a god.

truth_5.headline: Weaponize The Boring
truth_5.gap_description: Your 'Self-Expression' marker is perfectly aligned at 100%—'The Pragmatist' (1/5). In a beauty category obsessed with 'Glow' and 'Rituals', you are 'The Tool'. You aren't leaning into this hard enough. You are selling 'Convenience' when you could be selling 'Anti-Vanity.'
truth_5.why_matters: Competitors are trying to make balms 'sexy'. You win by being the 'Gym Bag Essential' that requires zero thought. This is the ultimate 'If you know, you know' flex. Leveraging this strength aggressively separates you from the 'beauty' noise.
truth_5.do_this_now: Create a 'What's In Your Bag' module in the A+ Content showing the stick alongside other utilitarian gear (sneakers, water bottle, keys). Frame it explicitly as 'The Essential Tool for Active Skin'—celebrating its lack of glamour as a feature.

marker_1.so_what: Strong territory match, but the source of authority has cooled. Strategy relies on the 'Doctor' (Human), while the PDP relies on the 'Molecule' (Clinical). Minor drift toward sterility.

marker_2.so_what: Flawless execution. The brand perfectly balances the 'Micro' scope (fixing cracked heels) with 'Democratic' access (mass price). This creates high trust.

marker_3.so_what: Territory holds, but transparency strategy drifts. Strategy wants to 'Explain' safety; PDP just lists the 'Specs'. This creates a colder, more technical user experience than intended.

marker_4.so_what: Perfect alignment. The 'Clinical Sterile' aesthetic and 'Daily Essential' pricing are lock-step. The brand successfully looks like a prescription you don't need a script for.

marker_5.so_what: Healthy, but risking arrogance. The PDP pushes Authority to the absolute max (5/5), answering questions with a definitive 'No' that borders on god-complex territory.

marker_6.so_what: Strong core alignment on Caregiver/Sage. Tertiary archetype drift (Everyman → Hero) is the only variance, shifting the focus slightly from 'for everyone' to 'for the active'.

marker_7.so_what: Near perfect. The slight uptick in Enthusiasm (1→2) on the PDP is negligible. The brand successfully speaks 'Pharmacist' on both channels.

marker_8.so_what: The visual sterility is maintained. The slight relaxation of the grid on Amazon (2/5) aids readability without breaking the 'Medical' feel.

marker_9.so_what: Consistent functional focus. The PDP relies slightly more on 'Rational' cause-and-effect logic (2/5) than the 'Raw Data' (1/5) of the site, which actually helps conversion.

marker_10.so_what: Total alignment on the 'No Story' story. The brand refuses to name a founder or show a home, sticking strictly to the Lab/Clinic context.

marker_11.so_what: Both channels rely on 'The Board' (Derms). The PDP shifts slightly to 'The Stat' (percentages) for proof, but the territory is secure.

marker_12.so_what: Strategy relies on the 'Hero' status of the ointment formula. PDP relies on the 'Tech' of the stick format. You are selling the package more than the potion on Amazon.

marker_13.so_what: Both channels treat content as education/thesis. The brand consistently refuses to entertain, choosing to inform instead.

marker_14.so_what: The brand is a 'Fixer' on all fronts. It does not promise maintenance; it promises repair. This clarity is a major asset.

marker_15.so_what: Locked in on 'Relief'. The brand understands it is sold to people in pain/discomfort, not people looking for luxury.

marker_16.so_what: Total alignment on being uncool. The brand embraces its role as a 'Tool' and 'Standard', ignoring trends to sell pure utility.

marker_17.so_what: The brand successfully leverages social proof as 'The Majority' choice. Buying Aquaphor is a signal of normalcy and safety.
